summary: A letter from the New Mexico Attorney General's Office to the Southern District of New York, providing investigative materials and offering cooperation in the investigation of Jeffrey Epstein's co-conspirators. It references crimes occurring in New Mexico prior to 2008 and emphasizes the need to continue the investigation despite Epstein's death.

persons.name: Hector H. Balderas
persons.context: The Attorney General of New Mexico, whose office is sending the correspondence and investigative materials to the Southern District of New York.

persons.name: Clara Moran
persons.context: The author of the letter, who signs off and offers direct contact for further cooperation regarding the Epstein investigation in New Mexico.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure in the criminal investigation; the letter discusses the investigation into his potential co-conspirators and crimes that occurred in New Mexico.

events.title: Enactment of New Mexico Human Trafficking Statute
events.description: New Mexico enacted its human-trafficking statute, which is referenced as a cutoff for the conduct described in the investigation.

events.title: Epstein's Death
events.description: Mentioned as an event that should not end the criminal inquiry into his activities and co-conspirators.

keyFacts: The New Mexico Attorney General's Office is providing investigative materials to the Southern District of New York regarding Jeffrey Epstein's co-conspirators.
The materials include police reports, witness interviews, inter-agency correspondence, and documents related to Epstein's leasing of New Mexico public lands.
All criminal conduct described in the New Mexico investigation occurred prior to 2008, the year the state enacted its human-trafficking statute.
The letter emphasizes that Epstein's death should not end the criminal inquiry and offers continued cooperation to identify survivors of crimes in New Mexico.
